summary: New York City is home to more than 3.2 million residents born outside the United States, the largest foreign-born population of any city in the world. The City of New York, usually called either New York City (NYC) or simply New York (NY), is the most populous city in the United States.The New York City Administrative Code, the New York City Rules, and the City Record are the code of local laws, compilation of regulations, and official journal, respectively.In 2006, the Sister City Program of the City of New York, Inc. was restructured and renamed New York City Global Partners.As of 2017, New York City was home to the highest number of billionaires of any city in the world at 103, including former Mayor Michael Bloomberg.Many large financial companies are headquartered in New York City, and the city is also home to a burgeoning number of financial startup companies.In 2019, New York was voted the greatest city in the world per a survey of over 30,000 people from 48 cities worldwide, citing the city's cultural diversity.The biotechnology sector is also growing in New York City, based upon the city's strength in academic scientific research and public and commercial financial support.New York City has the largest European and non-Hispanic white population of any American city.City residents and businesses also sent an additional $4.1 billion in the 2009–2010 fiscal year to the state of New York than the city received in return.

The Korea Times is the city's major daily Korean language paper while The World Journal is the city and county's major Chinese newspaper.Despite the congestion in the city, the mean travel time for commuters in Los Angeles is shorter than other major cities, including New York City, Philadelphia and Chicago.Also, Los Angeles is increasingly becoming a city of apartments rather than single family dwellings, especially in the dense inner city and Westside neighborhoods.Los Angeles City Council also designated seven industrial zones within the city.The largest employers in the city as of 2009[update] were, in descending order, the City of Los Angeles, the County of Los Angeles, and University of California, Los Angeles.With 621,000 Jews in the metropolitan area (490,000 in city proper), the region has the second largest population of Jews in the United States.The XFL Los Angeles are tenants of Dignity Health Sports Park Los Angeles is a charter city as opposed to a general law city.The city met its goal of providing 20 percent of the city's power from renewable sources in 2010.The Hispanic population has a long established Mexican-American and Central American community and is spread well-nigh throughout the entire city of Los Angeles and its metropolitan area.The city is also central to the commuter rail system Metrolink, which links Los Angeles to all neighboring counties as well as many suburbs.

Chicago's 58 million domestic and international visitors in 2018 made it the second most visited city in the nation, behind New York City's approximate 65 million visitors.The city ranked first place in the 2018 Time Out City Life Index, a global quality of life survey of 15,000 people in 32 cities.The South Side is the largest section of the city, encompassing roughly 60% of the city's land area.The North Side is the most densely populated residential section of the city, and many high-rises are located on this side of the city along the lakefront.The City Council is the legislative branch and is made up of 50 aldermen, one elected from each ward in the city.The City of Chicago was incorporated on Saturday, March 4, 1837, and for several decades was the world's fastest-growing city.The desire to join the city was driven by municipal services that the city could provide its residents.From 1928 to 1933, the city witnessed a tax revolt, and the city was unable to meet payroll or provide relief efforts.This was higher than in New York City and Los Angeles, the two largest cities in the United States, which have lower murder rates and lower total homicides.The Chicago Public Library system operates 79 public libraries, including the central library, two regional libraries, and numerous branches distributed throughout the city.

Other nicknames often used by locals include "Bayou City", "Clutch City", "Crush City", "Magnolia City", and "H-Town".The city's elected officials are the mayor, city controller and 16 members of the Houston City Council.Under the city charter, once the population in the city limits exceeded 2.1 million residents, two additional districts were to be added.In 2012, the city was ranked number one for paycheck worth by Forbes and in late May 2013, Houston was identified as America's top city for employment creation.Leading in healthcare sectors and building oilfield equipment, Houston has the second most Fortune 500 headquarters of any U.S. municipality within its city limits (after New York City).During 1991–2015, the city controller and city council members were subjected to a two-year, three-term limitation – the 2015 referendum amended term limits to two four-year terms.Many of them near the city worked on sugar and cotton plantations, while most of those in the city limits had domestic and artisan jobs.The city has often been known to be the most politically diverse city in Texas, a state known for being generally conservative.Much of the city's wealthier areas vote Republican while the city's working class and minority areas vote Democratic.Nicknamed the "Space City" and "H-Town", Houston has become a global city, with strengths in culture, medicine, and research.

Not since 1940–50, when the city had a population of 107,000, had the city gained less than 124,000 in a decade.It is also the fifth most populous city in the United States and the only state capital with a population of more than one million residents.The population density is 2,797.8 people per square mile, and the median age of the city is 32.2 years, with only 10.9 of the population being over 62.The construction industry, spurred on by the city's growth, further expanded with the development of Sun City.The city of Phoenix includes national parks, county (Maricopa County) parks and city parks.Today, the city is served by one major daily newspaper: The Arizona Republic, which along with its online entity, azcentral.com, serves the greater metropolitan area.The city offices were moved into the new City Hall at Washington and Central in 1888.The city council consists of a mayor and eight city council members.Even though it is the fifth most populated city, the large area gives it a low density rate of approximately 2,797 people per square mile.The mayor and city council members each have equal voting power in regards to setting city policy and passing rules and regulations.

The City Planning Commission, tasked with guiding growth and development of the city, has divided the city into 18 planning districts as part of the Philadelphia2035 physical development plan.The city grew from an influx of European immigrants, most of whom came from Ireland, Italy and Germany—the three largest reported ancestry groups in the city as of 2015[update].As of 2014[update], the total city parkland, including municipal, state and federal parks within the city limits, amounts to 11,211 acres (17.5 sq mi).Center City had an estimated 183,240 residents as of 2015[update], making it the second-most populated downtown area in the United States, after Midtown Manhattan in New York City.The city became a member of the Organization of World Heritage Cities in 2015, as the first World Heritage City in the United States.Philadelphia's neighborhoods are divided into large sections—North, Northeast, South, Southwest Philadelphia, West, and Northwest—surrounding Center City, which corresponds closely with the city's limits before consolidation in 1854.The city's two largest employers are the federal and city governments.The city's 25- to 29-year-old age group was the city's largest age cohort.The 548 ft (167 m) City Hall remained the tallest building in the city until 1987 when One Liberty Place was completed.Founded in 1836, the company came under city ownership in 1987 and has been providing the majority of gas distributed within city limits.

San Antonio became the largest American city without an intra-city rail system when Phoenix, the former largest city without such a system, procured one in 2008.The city is home to one of the largest concentrations of military bases in the U.S., and has been nicknamed Military City, USA.Downtown San Antonio, the city and metro area's urban core, encompasses many of the city's famous structures, attractions, and businesses.The River Walk, which meanders through the Downtown area, is the city's second-most-visited attraction, giving it the additional nickname of "River City".VIA also offers a special service to city events including Spurs games and city parades from its park and ride locations.According to the 2000 U.S. Census, the city proper had a population of 1,144,646, ranking it the ninth-most populated city in the country.Due to the size of the city and its horizontal development, downtown accounts for less than one half of one percent of San Antonio's geographic area.San Antonio is also home to a campus of The Culinary Institute of America The city is home to more than 30 private schools and charter schools.The largest Baptist bodies in the city and metro area are the Baptist General Convention of Texas and Southern Baptist Convention.In the 2000s the city annexed several long narrow corridors along major thoroughfares in outlying areas to facilitate eventual annexation of growth developing along the routes.

The city has two major commercial airports within or near its city limits.Two years later the city was bankrupt; the California legislature revoked the city's charter and placed it under control of a board of trustees, where it remained until 1889.The members of the city council are each elected from single-member districts within the city.According to the City's 2016 Comprehensive Annual Financial Report, the top employers in the city are: San Diego has high real estate prices.The mayor and city attorney are elected directly by the voters of the entire city.The city recognized the importance of its neighborhoods when it organized its 2008 General Plan around the concept of a "City of Villages".In 2007, registered Democrats outnumbered Republicans by about 7 to 6 in the city, and Democrats currently (as of 2018[update]) hold a 6–3 majority in the city council.The city is governed by a mayor and a nine-member city council.The census ranks the city as the ninth-most educated city in the United States, based on these figures.A city charter was reestablished in 1889, and today's city charter was adopted in 1931.

Several companies maintain the city's electric system, including Stream Energy, Cirro Energy and Oncor Electric Delivery, whose parent company, Energy Future Holdings Corporation, has headquarters in the city.The city of Dallas operates WRR 101.1 FM, the area's main classical music station, from city offices in Fair Park.The southeastern portion of the city Pleasant Grove is chiefly inhabited by black and Hispanic or Latino residents, while the southern portion of the city is predominantly black.Fire protection and emergency medical services in the city are provided by Dallas Fire-Rescue Department, which has 1,800 firefighters and 58 working fire stations in the city limits.The city is also home to Texas's first and largest zoo, the 106-acre (0.43 km2) Dallas Zoo, which opened at its current location in 1888.The city has a population from a myriad of ethnic and religious backgrounds and the one of the largest LGBT communities in the U.S. and the largest in Texas.Broadnax serving as city manager, and 14 council members serving as representatives to the 14 council districts in the city.In addition to those in the city, the surrounding cities also has a number of universities, colleges, trade schools, and other educational institutions.What was once an area characterized by high rates of poverty and crime is now one of the city's most attractive social and living destinations.The west and east sides of the city are predominantly Hispanic or Latino; Garland also has a large Spanish speaking population.

Other city officers directly appointed by the council include the City Attorney, City Auditor, City Clerk, and Independent Police Auditor.The city has a council-manager government with a city manager nominated by the mayor and elected by the city council.The City Manager is the chief administrative officer of the city, and must present an annual budget for approval by the city council.The San Jose City Council is made up of ten council members elected by district, and a mayor elected by the entire city.[citation needed] During the 1950s and 1960s, City Manager A. P. "Dutch" Hamann led the city in a major growth campaign.With a total population of 1,015,785, San Jose became the 11th U.S. city to hit the 1 million mark, even though it is currently the 10th most populous city.Households in the city limits have the highest disposable income of any city in the U.S. with over 500,000 residents.In 1957, when the city established a relationship with Okayama, Japan, it was only the third Sister City relationship in the nation, which had begun the prior year.Recently, the city had the second lowest violent crime rate of any city with 500,000 or more residents, only behind Honolulu.The city's name without the accent can still be found in its 1965 Charter document, as amended, which formally chartered the municipality as City of San Jose.

Austin City Limits and C3 Presents produce the Austin City Limits Music Festival, an annual music and art festival held at Zilker Park in Austin.For the 2018 Austin City Limits Music Festival, the city of Austin offered a designated parking area for dockless bikes and scooters.Austin is known as the most bike-friendly city in Texas, and was ranked the #7 city in the US by Bicycling Magazine in 2016.Austin Executive Airport serves the general aviation coming into the city, as well as other smaller airports outside of the city center.The city briefly banned the scooters - which were operating without a permit - until the city unveiled their "dockless mobility" permitting process on May 1, 2018.It is the 11th-most populous city in the United States and the 4th-most populous city in Texas.The city is also home to the Ballet East Dance Company, a modern dance ensemble, and the Tapestry Dance Company which performs a variety of dance genres.The city is the cultural and economic center of the Austin–Round Rock metropolitan statistical area, which had an estimated population of 2,168,316 as of July 1, 2018[update].The city also adopted "Silicon Hills" as a nickname in the 1990s due to a rapid influx of technology and development companies.The three-day Austin City Limits Music Festival has been held in Zilker Park every year since 2002.

Jacksonville is the most populous city in Florida, the most populous city in the southeastern United States and the largest city by area in the contiguous United States.According to Article 21 of the Jacksonville City Charter, JEA is authorized to own, manage and operate a utilities system within and outside the City of Jacksonville.U.S. Highway 1 (US 1) and US 17 travel through the city from the south to the north, and US 23 enters the city running concurrently with US 1.Jacksonville is organized under the city charter and provides for a "strong" mayor–council form of city government.Austin oversaw the city's purchase and refurbishing of the St. James Building, which would eventually become Jacksonville's city hall.On October 1, 1968, the city and county governments merged to create the Consolidated City of Jacksonville.Jacksonville is also home of River City Pride which is Northeast Florida's largest Gay Pride parade.The city is home to one of the largest collections of Prairie School style buildings outside the Midwest.Jacksonville is the most populous city in Florida, and the twelfth most populous city in the United States.Jacksonville also has several quasi-independent government agencies which only nominally answer to the consolidated authority, including electric authority, port authority, transportation authority, housing authority and airport authority.

Excluded by state segregation from the business end of town and the more costly residential areas, the city's black citizens settled into the southern portion of the city.The day-to-day operations of city government are overseen by the city manager, who is also appointed by the council.It is the 13th-largest city in the United States and fifth-largest city in Texas.Fort Worth is home to these four airports within city limits: A 2011 study by Walk Score ranked Fort Worth 47th-most walkable of 50 largest U.S. cities.Fort Worth is the second-largest city in the Dallas–Fort Worth–Arlington metropolitan area, which is the 4th most populous metropolitan area in the United States.Originally named Amon Carter Field after one of the city's influential mayors, Greater Southwest opened in 1953 and operated as the primary airport for Fort Worth until 1974.[citation needed] Today, the city of Fort Worth and many residents are dealing with the benefits and issues associated with the natural gas reserves under ground.Gradually, the cowboys began to avoid the area; as businesses suffered, the city moderated its opposition.There are two off-leash dog parks located in the city, ZBonz Dog Park and Fort Woof.The current mayor is Republican Betsy Price, making Fort Worth the largest city in the United States with a female Republican mayor.

1 up-and-coming tech city in the nation by Forbes in 2008, and the city was ranked a top-ten city by Relocate America in 2010.The city's primary airport, John Glenn International Airport (CMH), is on the city's east side, with several smaller airports in the region as well.In 2012, Forbes Magazine ranked the city as the best city for working moms.In 1894, James Thurber, who would go on to an illustrious literary career in Paris and New York City, was born in the city.To protect the city's tax base from this suburbanization, Columbus adopted a policy of linking sewer and water hookups to annexation to the city.The area's second largest school district is South-Western City Schools, which encompasses southwestern Franklin County.By the early 1990s, Columbus had grown to become Ohio's largest city in land area and in population.June's second-to-last weekend sees one of the Midwest's largest gay pride parades, reflecting the city's sizable gay population.This library is one of the country's most-used library systems and is consistently among the top-ranked large city libraries according to "Hennen's American Public Library Ratings."Including city, county, state, and federal employers, government jobs provide the largest single source of employment within Columbus.

The top employer in the city is the city government itself, employing 5.6% (31,000+ people) of the city's workforce, followed by UCSF with over 25,000 employees.The Tenderloin District is home to a large portion of the city's Vietnamese population as well as businesses and restaurants, which is known as the city's Little Saigon.The Tenderloin area has the highest crime rate in San Francisco: 70% of the city's violent crimes, and around one-fourth of the city's murders, occur in this neighborhood.San Francisco's status as the West Coast's largest city peaked between 1870 and 1900, when around 25% of California's population resided in the city proper.The city is believed to have the highest number of homeless inhabitants per capita of any major U.S. city.Tourism is one of the city's largest private-sector industries, accounting for more than one out of seven jobs in the city.The largest and best-known city park is Golden Gate Park, which stretches from the center of the city west to the Pacific Ocean.The high hills in the geographic center of the city are responsible for a 20% variance in annual rainfall between different parts of the city.Immigrant laborers made the city a polyglot culture, with Chinese Railroad Workers, drawn to "Old Gold Mountain", creating the city's Chinatown quarter.The city's frequent portrayal in music, film, and popular culture has made the city and its landmarks recognizable worldwide.

Charlotte was listed as the 20th largest city in the US, and the 60th fastest growing city in the US between 2000 and 2008.The city's public school system, Charlotte-Mecklenburg Schools, is the 2nd largest in North Carolina and 17th largest in the nation.Many students, researchers, and affiliated professionals live near UNC Charlotte in the northeast area known as University City.According to the Congressional Quarterly Press; '2008 City Crime Rankings: Crime in Metropolitan America,' Charlotte, North Carolina ranks as the 62nd most dangerous city larger than 75,000 inhabitants.It is located in University City, the northeastern portion of Charlotte, which is also home to University Research Park, a 3,200 acres (13 km2) research and corporate park.Measured by control of assets, Charlotte became the second largest banking headquarters in the United States, after New York City.In the 1920 census, Charlotte lost its title as the state's largest city to Winston-Salem, which with a population of 48,395 had 2,077 more people than Charlotte.The Charlotte metropolitan area is part of a sixteen-county market region or combined statistical area with a 2016 census-estimated population of 2,632,249.Independence Freeway, which carries U.S. 74 and links downtown with the Matthews area, is undergoing an expansion and widening in the eastern part of the city.Though the Catawba River and its lakes lie several miles west, there are no significant bodies of water or other geological features near the city center.

Samuel Henderson, the city's first mayor, led the new city government, which included a seven-member city council.Founded in 1821 as the city's public market, the Indianapolis City Market has served the community from its current building since 1886.Three intercity bus service providers stop in the city: Greyhound Lines and Burlington Trailways (via Union Station), and Megabus (via City Market).As consumer habits evolved and residents moved from the central city, the City Market transitioned from a traditional marketplace to a food court, a function it retains today.In 1853, voters approved a new city charter that provided for an elected mayor and a fourteen-member city council.The city's balance excludes the populations of ten semi-autonomous municipalities that are included in totals for the consolidated city.The U.S. Census Bureau considers Indianapolis as two entities: the consolidated city and the city's remainder, or balance.The city's Hispanic or Latino community comprised 9.4% of the city's population in the 2010 U.S. Census: 6.9% Mexican, 0.4% Puerto Rican, 0.1% Cuban, and 2% as other.Two of the city's nicknames reflect its historical ties to transportation—the "Crossroads of America" and "Railroad City".Indianapolis covers 368 square miles (950 km2), making it the 16th largest city by land area in the U.S. Indigenous peoples inhabited the area dating to approximately 2000 BC.

In July 2017, the Seattle City Council unanimously approved an income tax on Seattle residents, making the city the only one in the state with an income tax.By comparison, Fort Myers, Florida, reports thunder on 93 days per year, Kansas City on 52, and New York City on 25.Although the Seattle Fault passes just south of the city center, neither it nor the Cascadia subduction zone has caused an earthquake since the city's founding.Conversely, the city receives some of the lowest precipitation amounts of any large city from June to September.The SuperSonics relocated to Oklahoma City and became the Oklahoma City Thunder for the 2008–09 season.The city's chief harbor, Elliott Bay, is part of Puget Sound, which makes the city an oceanic port.With work projects close to the city, Hooverville grew and the WPA settled into the city.Despite having a reputation for frequent rain, Seattle receives less precipitation than many other U.S. cities like Chicago or New York City.King County Metro provides frequent stop bus service within the city and surrounding county, as well as the South Lake Union Streetcar line and the First Hill Streetcar line.The mayor's office also includes two deputy mayors, appointed to advise the mayor on policies; As of 2017[update], the city's deputy mayors are Michael Fong and Shefali Ranganathan.

Denver is the most populous city within a 500-mile (800 km) radius and the second-most populous city in the Mountain West after Phoenix, Arizona.In the early days of the city, gold and silver booms and busts played a large role in the city's economic success.Reinhard Schuetze was the city's first landscape architect, and he brought his German-educated landscaping genius to Washington Park, Cheesman Park, and City Park among others.As of the 2010 census, the population of the City and County of Denver was 600,158, making it the 24th most populous U.S. city.Denver is the most populous city within a radius centered in the city and of 550-mile (890 km) magnitude.The young city grew during these years, attracting millionaires with their mansions, as well as the poverty and crime of a rapidly growing city.As of January 2013, the City and County of Denver has defined 78 official neighborhoods that the city and community groups use for planning and administration.This coincided with the City Beautiful movement, and Denver mayor Robert Speer (1904–12 and 1916–18) set out to expand and beautify the city's parks.As of 2006[update], Denver had over 200 parks, from small mini-parks all over the city to the giant 314-acre (1.27 km2) City Park.The city also plans to invest billions to bringing frequent public transit within one-fourth of a mile of most of its residents.

The city's first motorized streetcars began service in 1888 and generated growth in areas of the District beyond the City of Washington's original boundaries.Washington was the first city in the nation to undergo urban renewal projects as part of the "City Beautiful movement" in the early 1900s.The creek also formed a portion of the now-filled Washington City Canal, which allowed passage through the city to the Anacostia River from 1815 until the 1850s.Paris and Rome are each formally recognized as a partner city due to their special one sister city policy.World War II further increased government activity, adding to the number of federal employees in the capital; by 1950, the District's population reached its peak of 802,178 residents.Each of the city's eight wards elects a single member of the council and residents elect four at-large members to represent the District as a whole.The Washington Metropolitan Area, which includes the District and surrounding suburbs, is the sixth-largest metropolitan area in the United States with an estimated 6 million residents in 2014.Commuters from the surrounding Maryland and Virginia suburbs raise the city's daytime population to more than one million during the workweek.The city is also one of the most visited cities in the world, with more than 20 million tourists annually.Listed in the order each agreement was first established, they are: District of Columbia Public Schools (DCPS) operates the city's 123 public schools.

In 2000, non-Hispanic whites made up 49.5% of the city's population, making the city majority minority for the first time.At the time Boston was chartered as a city, the population was about 46,226, while the area of the city was only 4.7 square miles (12 km2).The city proper covers 48 square miles (124 km2) with an estimated population of 694,583 in 2018, making it also the most populous city in New England.The city is a center for contemporary classical music with a number of performing groups, several of which are associated with the city's conservatories and universities.Boston is sometimes called a "city of neighborhoods" because of the profusion of diverse subsections; the city government's Office of Neighborhood Services has officially designated 23 neighborhoods.Manufacturing became an important component of the city's economy, and the city's industrial manufacturing overtook international trade in economic importance by the mid-19th century.Snowfall increases dramatically as one goes inland away from the city (especially north and west of the city)—away from the moderating influence of the ocean.The city is the third-most densely populated large U.S. city of over half a million residents.In the latter half of the 19th century, the city saw increasing numbers of Irish, Germans, Lebanese, Syrians, French Canadians, and Russian and Polish Jews settling in the city.The city uses an algorithm created by the Walsh administration, called CityScore, to measure the effectiveness of various city services.

In 1977, El Paso City Lines and two other bus companies were bought by the municipality and merged to form Sun City Area Transit (SCAT).El Paso was the largest city in the United States without a PBS television station within the city limits until 1978.It is the third largest area of the city, behind east El Paso and central El Paso.It is considered a small range (23 miles long, 3 miles (4.8 km) wide) that extends from city north into New Mexico.El Paso City and County vote overwhelmingly Democratic, like most of the Texas–Mexico border area and urban Texas.According to the United States Census Bureau, the city has a total area of 256.3 square miles (663.7 km2).Some people in this area and its twin city across the river, Ciudad Juárez, are direct descendants of the Spaniards.The El Paso II District Parole Office is in an unincorporated area east of Horizon City.The west side is home to some of the most affluent neighborhoods within the city, such as the Coronado Hills and Country Club neighborhoods.The Franklin Mountains State Park, with its more than 24,248 acres (9,813 ha), is completely located within the city limits.

As of 2013[update] there are four Catholic grade schools and three Catholic high schools in the City of Detroit, with all of them in the city's west side.Young was criticized for being too focused on downtown development and not doing enough to lower the city's high crime rate and improve city services.One of the largest post-bankruptcy efforts to improve city services has been work to fix the city's broken street lighting system.The city has numerous neighborhoods consisting of vacant properties resulting in low inhabited density in those areas, stretching city services and infrastructure.At its peak population of 1,849,568, in the 1950 Census, the city was the 5th-largest in the United States, after New York City, Chicago, Philadelphia and Los Angeles.To counteract this, the city used eminent domain to build two large new auto assembly plants in the city.Young also gave city support to other large developments to attract middle and upper-class residents back to the city.The city became the 4th-largest in the nation in 1920, after only New York City, Chicago and Philadelphia, with the influence of the booming auto industry.As mayor, Young sought to revive the city by seeking to increase investment in the city's declining downtown.In 2013, Detroit became the largest U.S. city to file for bankruptcy, which it successfully exited in December 2014, when the city government regained control of Detroit's finances.

According to the city's 2016 Comprehensive Annual Financial Report, the top employers in the city are: Much of the city's cultural life has revolved around its large university community.Circa 1950 the state legislature approved a new city charter that provided for the election of city council members from single-member districts, rather than at-large voting.In May 2018, AllianceBernstein pledged to build a private client office in the city by mid-2019 and to move its headquarters from New York City to Nashville by 2024.Thanks in part to Nashville's foodie culture, the city was ranked as the 13th "snobbiest" city in America according to Travel + Leisure magazine.The city is served by Nashville International Airport (BNA), and is a focus city for Southwest Airlines and was a hub for American Airlines between 1986 and 1995.Pockets of Republican influence exist in the wealthier portions of the city, but they are usually no match for the overwhelming Democratic trend in the rest of the city.Interstate 840 provides a southern Bypass for the city, and a Bypass for I-40 for the city and its suburbs.The city is also home to two minor league teams: the Nashville Sounds of Minor League Baseball's Pacific Coast League and Nashville SC of the USL Championship.Nashville is also home to the NCAA college football Music City Bowl.Reflecting the city's position in state government, Nashville is home to the Tennessee Supreme Court's courthouse for Middle Tennessee.

Portland has the most breweries and independent microbreweries of any city in the world, with 58 active breweries within city limits and 70+ within the surrounding metro area.Downtown Portland straddles the banks of the Willamette River, which flows north through the city center and separates the city's east and west neighborhoods.The city became a pioneer of state-directed metropolitan planning, a program which was instituted statewide in 1969 to compact the urban growth boundaries of the city.The city receives frequent acclaim as the best beer city in the United States and is consistently ranked as one of the top-five beer destinations in the world.The Willamette River divides the city into east and west while Burnside Street, which traverses the entire city lengthwise, divides the north and south.The city's Community & Civic Life (formerly Office of Neighborhood Involvement) serves as a conduit between city government and Portland's 95 officially recognized neighborhoods.General John DeWitt called the city the first "Jap free city on the West Coast."By the early 20th century, the city had lost its reputation as a "sober frontier city" and garnered a reputation for being violent and dangerous.Popular Science awarded Portland the title of the Greenest City in America in 2008, and Grist magazine listed it in 2007 as the second greenest city in the world.The city's Crystal Ballroom became a hub for the city's psychedelic culture, while food cooperatives and listener-funded media and radio stations were established.

Beginning in 1963, Memphis adopted a mayor-council form of government, with 13 City Council members, six elected at-large from throughout the city and seven elected from geographic districts.Memphis barbecue has achieved international prominence, and the city hosts the World Championship Barbecue Cooking Contest, which attracts over 100,000 visitors to the city annually.The city had authority for this action under Tennessee state laws that differentiate between city and county powers.None had the means to flee the city, as did the middle and upper class whites of Memphis, and thus they were subjected to a city of death.By the early 20th century, Memphis had two major passenger railroad stations, which made the city a regional hub for trains coming from the north, east, south and west.The total metropolitan area has a higher proportion of whites and a higher per capita income than the population in the city.Located in the low-lying delta region along the river, its outlying areas were developed as cotton plantations, and the city became a major cotton market and brokerage center.The city now has a majority-black population; the larger metropolitan area is narrowly majority white.Attracting workers from rural areas as well as new immigrants, from 1900 to 1950 the city increased nearly fourfold in population, from 102,350 to 396,000 residents.They also gained many elected and patronage positions in the Democratic Party city government, and an Irish man was elected as mayor before the Civil War.

Oklahoma City is the principal city of the eight-county Oklahoma City Metropolitan Statistical Area in Central Oklahoma and is the state's largest urbanized area.The Oklahoma City metropolitan area is one of the most tornado-prone major cities in the world, with about 150 tornadoes striking within the city limits since 1890.The City of Oklahoma City has operated under a council-manager form of city government since 1927.With the 1928 discovery of oil within the city limits (including under the State Capitol), Oklahoma City became a major center of oil production.Oklahoma City also has several major national and state highways within its city limits.Oklahoma City is home to the state's largest school district, Oklahoma City Public Schools.The Thunder play home games at the Chesapeake Energy Arena in downtown Oklahoma City, known affectionately in the national media as 'the Peake' and 'Loud City'.The Midwest Regional Medical Center is in the suburb of Midwest City; other major hospitals in the city include the Oklahoma Heart Hospital and the Mercy Health Center.Oklahoma City also has two amusement parks, Frontier City theme park and White Water Bay water park.Since 2008, Oklahoma City has been home to the National Basketball Association (NBA)'s Oklahoma City Thunder, who play their home games at the Chesapeake Energy Arena.

As with most major metropolitan areas, the name of the primary city ("Las Vegas" in this case) is often used to describe areas beyond official city limits.The city anchors the Las Vegas Valley metropolitan area and is the largest city within the greater Mojave Desert.In 2016, 77.1 percent of working Las Vegas residents (those living in the city, but not necessarily working in the city) commuted by driving alone.The City Manager is responsible for the administration and the day-to-day operations of all municipal services and city departments.US 95 connects the city to northwestern Nevada, including Carson City and Reno.The mountains immediately surrounding the Las Vegas Valley accumulate snow every winter, but significant accumulation within the city is rare, although moderate accumulations do occur every few years.During this time the city was nicknamed the "Atomic City".The area is also served by two NOAA Weather Radio transmitters (162.55 MHz located in Boulder City and 162.40 MHz located on Mount Potosi).The former City Hall building is now occupied by the corporate headquarters for the major online retailer, Zappos.com, which opened downtown in 2013.The city is home to an extensive Downtown Arts District, which hosts numerous galleries and events including the annual Las Vegas Film Festival.

In its first season, Louisville City was the official reserve side for Orlando City SC while making its debut in Major League Soccer at the same time.Today the city is served by two major freight railroads, CSX (with a major classification yard in the southern part of the metro area) and Norfolk Southern.Due to the city-county merger that occurred in 2003, which expanded the city limits, the city's population increased to 597,337 at the 2010 census count. Louisville (/ˈluːəvəl/ (listen) LOO-ə-vəl, /ˈluːivɪl/ (listen) LOO-ee-vil, /ˈlʊvəl/ (listen) LUUV-əl) is the largest city in the Commonwealth of Kentucky and the 29th most-populous city in the United States.Multiple art galleries are located in the city, but they are especially concentrated in the East Market District (NuLu), immediately to the east of downtown.The city is also a major center of the American whiskey industry, with about one-third of all bourbon coming from Louisville.A free TARC bus takes art lovers to many downtown area (especially East Market District/NuLu) independent art galleries on the first Friday of every month.Another primary business and industrial district is located in the suburban area east of the city on Hurstbourne Parkway.Two regional railroads, the Paducah and Louisville Railway and the Louisville and Indiana Railroad, also serve the city.[d] It is one of two cities in Kentucky designated as first-class, the other being Lexington, the state's second-largest city.

The city is also located on the fall line between the Piedmont Plateau and the Atlantic coastal plain, which divides Baltimore into "lower city" and "upper city".In 2011, the city undertook a campaign to reconstruct many sidewalk ramps in the city, coinciding with mass resurfacing of the city's streets.Baltimore City College (also known as "City") and Baltimore Polytechnic Institute (also known as "Poly") share the nation's second-oldest high school football rivalry.The city grew in area by annexing new suburbs from the surrounding counties through 1918, when the city acquired portions of Baltimore County and Anne Arundel County.Nearly one third of the city's buildings (over 65,000) are designated as historic in the National Register, which is more than any other U.S. city.The city remained a part of surrounding Baltimore County and continued to serve as its county seat from 1768 to 1851, after which it became an independent city.Campus and building security for the city's public schools is provided by the Baltimore City Public Schools Police, established in the 1970s.To put that in perspective, New York City, a city with a 2015 population of 8,491,079 recorded a total of 339 homicides in 2015.After New York City, Baltimore was the second city in the United States to reach a population of 100,000.The Baltimore City Department of Recreation and Parks manages the majority of parks and recreational facilities in the city including Patterson Park, Federal Hill Park, and Druid Hill Park.

Because many of the city's buildings were built using this material it earned the nickname "Cream City", and consequently the brick was called Cream City brick.The city had previously established free wireless networks in two downtown city parks: Cathedral Square; and Pere Marquette Park.As part of the city's Bicycle and Pedestrian Task Force's mission to "make Milwaukee more bicycle and pedestrian friendly", over 700 bike racks have been installed throughout the city. Milwaukee (/mɪlˈwɔːki/, locally /mɪˈ-/) is the largest city in the state of Wisconsin and the fifth-largest city in the Midwestern United States.Responding to this problem, in 2009 the city became an "Innovating City" in the Global Compact Cities Program.Milwaukee's founding fathers had a vision for the city: they knew it was perfectly situated as a port city, a center for collecting and distributing produce.Since Polish-American immigrants to the area prized land ownership, this solution, which was prominent in their areas of settlement within the city, came to be associated with them.The largest Italian-American festival in the area, Festa Italiana, is held in the city.In 1818, the French Canadian explorer Solomon Juneau settled in the area, and in 1846, Juneau's town combined with two neighboring towns to incorporate as the city of Milwaukee.In 2010, the Census Bureau released revised population numbers for Milwaukee that showed the city gained population, growing by 1.3%, between 2000 and 2009.

It is unclear at this time whether the Santolina development will be annexed into the City of Albuquerque or incorporated into its own city when its development does occur.The city proper is bordered on the north by the North Valley, the village of Corrales, and the city of Rio Rancho.:177–181 Today, Alvarado Station provides convenient access to other parts of the city via the city bus system, ABQ RIDE.:VII The Albuquerque City Council is the legislative authority of the city, and has the power to adopt all ordinances, resolutions, or other legislation.Trash and recycling in the city is managed by the City of Albuquerque Solid Waste Management Department.The city is served by one major newspaper, the Albuquerque Journal, and several smaller daily and weekly papers, including the alternative Weekly Alibi.Newer suburban subdivisions on the West Mesa near the southwestern city limits join homes of older construction, some dating back as far as the 1940s.Some of the most affluent neighborhoods in the city are located here, including: High Desert, Tanoan, Sandia Heights, and North Albuquerque Acres.Additionally, the North Valley settlement, outside the city limits, which has some expensive homes and small ranches along the Rio Grande, is located here.Flora or vegetation surrounding the built portions of the city are typical of their desert southwestern and interior west setting, within the varied elevations and terrain.

Major incorporated suburbs of Tucson include Oro Valley and Marana northwest of the city, Sahuarita south of the city, and South Tucson in an enclave south of downtown.A major city in the Arizona Sun Corridor, Tucson is the largest city in southern Arizona, and the second largest in the state after Phoenix.It is generally classified as the area of the city east of Swan Road, with above-average real estate values relative to the rest of the city.The city of Tucson operates Ryan Airfield 13 miles southwest of the city center, and the town of Marana operates Marana Regional Airport 15 miles to the northwest.It is also the largest city in the area of the historic Gadsden Purchase.Brazelton had been suspected of highway robbery in the Tucson area, the Prescott region, and the Silver City, New Mexico area.Tucson is the 33rd largest city and the 58th largest metropolitan area in the United States (2014).Also on the north side is the suburban community of Catalina Foothills, located in the foothills of the Santa Catalina Mountains just north of the city limits.Tucson is the only city in Arizona that holds officially partisan elections for city offices, with candidates being nominated through party primaries.The 2010 United States Census puts the city's population at 520,116 with a metropolitan area population at 980,263.

The survey measures median park size, park acres as percent of city area, residents' access to parks, spending on parks per resident, and playgrounds per 10,000 residents.† Died in office The Fresno City Council is made up of seven members, elected by district: The City Council meets at Fresno City Hall.Likewise, Sierra National Forest is 40 mi (64 km), Kings Canyon National Park is 60 mi (97 km) and Sequoia National Park is 75 mi (121 km).In partnership with the City of Clovis, the City of Fresno opened the Community Media Access Collaborative (CMAC) in April 2012, a public, education and government access television station.Just 60 mi (97 km) south of Yosemite National Park, it is the nearest major city to the park.Although parts of Sunnyside are within the City of Fresno, much of the neighborhood is a "county island" within Fresno County.Fresno has three large public parks, two in the city limits and one in county land to the southwest.The "West Side" of Fresno, also often called "Southwest Fresno", is one of the oldest neighborhoods in the city.The Tower District neighborhood is just north of downtown Fresno proper, and one-half mile south of Fresno City College.[citation needed] The area is also known for its early twentieth century homes, many of which have been restored in recent decades.

Mesa is the largest suburban city by population in the United States, the third-largest city in Arizona after Phoenix and Tucson, and the 36th-largest city overall in the US.Note that this same road (as Arizona Avenue) serves as the official east and west numbering point of origin within the city of Chandler, located south of Mesa.It is also home to the largest relief airport in the Phoenix area, Phoenix-Mesa Gateway Airport, which is located in the southeastern corner of the city.Phoenix-Mesa Gateway Airport is located in the far southeastern area of the city, and provides alternate but limited air service when compared to Sky Harbor International Airport.It is a suburb located about 20 miles (32 km) east of Phoenix in the East Valley section of the Phoenix Metropolitan Area.Center Street, running north to south, bisects Mesa into eastern and western halves and serves as the east and west numbering point of origin within Mesa.The median income for a household in the city was $42,817, and the median income for a family was $49,232.Mesa Riverview is a new outdoor destination retail center in the northwestern corner of the city, near Loop 202 and Dobson Road.Rather than accepting an invitation to settle at Jones' Lehi settlement, they moved to the top of the mesa that serves as the city's namesake.In 1883, Mesa City was incorporated with a population of 300 people.

This area was not originally part of the City of Sacramento and as such is not served by Sacramento City Unified School District.The Government of Sacramento operates as a charter city (as opposed to a general law city) under the Charter of the City of Sacramento.The area is also home to many of the city's LGBTQ inclusive music and arts festivals, including the Second Saturday Block Party from May to September.In 2002, the Civil Rights Project at Harvard University conducted for Time magazine named Sacramento "America's Most Diverse City".The Campus Commons area and the small portions of the Sierra Oaks neighborhood that fall into the city of Sacramento are served by the San Juan Unified School District.Business 80 (the Capital City Freeway) splits from I-80 in West Sacramento, runs through Sacramento, and then rejoins its parent in the northwest portion of the city.Most arrived at San Francisco, which was then the largest city in California and known as "Dai Fow" ("Big City", Chinese: 大埠, Jyutping: daai6 fau6).The elected government is composed of the Sacramento City Council with 8 city council districts and the Mayor of Sacramento, which operate under a mayor-council government.For commercial reasons the new city was named "Sacramento City," after the Sacramento River.Some eventually came to Sacramento, then the second-largest city in California and consequently called "Yee Fow" ("Second City", Chinese: 二埠, Jyutping: ji6 fau6).

From 2000 to 2010, the city's black population decreased by 31,678 people, shrinking from 61.4% of the city's population in 2000 to 54.0% in 2010.Buckhead, the city's uptown district, is eight miles (13 km) north of Downtown and the city's third-largest business district.Vine City, though technically Northwest, adjoins the city's Downtown area and has recently been the target of community outreach programs and economic development initiatives.Between 2000 and 2010, the proportion of whites in the city's population grew faster than any other U.S. city.The city council consists of 15 representatives—one from each of the city's 12 districts and three at-large positions.The city is served by the Atlanta Police Department, which numbers 2,000 officers and oversaw a 40% decrease in the city's crime rate between 2001 and 2009.Running is a popular local sport, and the city declares itself to be "Running City USA".The city serves as the cultural and economic center of the Atlanta metropolitan area, home to 5.8 million people and the ninth-largest metropolitan area in the nation.Due to the more than 20 colleges and universities in the city, Atlanta is considered one of the nation's largest hubs for higher education.Religion in Atlanta, while historically centered on Protestant Christianity, now involves many faiths as a result of the city and metro area's increasingly international population.

During the heyday of the Kansas City Stockyards, the city was known for its Kansas City steaks or Kansas City strip steaks.The city is served by two major faith-oriented newspapers: The Kansas City Metro Voice, serving the Christian community, and the Kansas City Jewish Chronicle, serving the Jewish community.In 1955, Kansas City became a major league city when the Philadelphia Athletics baseball franchise relocated to the city in 1955.The Mayor, City Council, and City Manager are listed below: Kansas City hosted the 1900 Democratic National Convention, the 1928 Republican National Convention and the 1976 Republican National Convention.In 2018, UNESCO named Kansas City as a "City of Music," making it the only city in the United States with that distinction.The mayor is the head of the Kansas City City Council, which has 12 members (one member for each district, plus one at large member per district).It is the central city of the Kansas City metropolitan area, which straddles the Kansas–Missouri state line.Ward Parkway, on the west side of the city near State Line Road, is lined by many of the city's largest and most elaborate homes.Swope Park is one of the nation's largest city parks, comprising 1,805 acres (3 sq mi), more than twice the size of New York City's Central Park.Kansas City native Robert Altman directed movies at the Calvin Company, which led him to shoot his first feature film, The Delinquents, in Kansas City using many local players.

Alexander Airport north of the city opened in 1925, and in 1927 the original Colorado Springs Municipal Airport land was purchased east of the city.At 6,035 feet (1,839 m) the city stands over 1 mile (1.6 km) above sea level, though some areas of the city are significantly higher and lower.Part of the territory included in the United States' 1803 Louisiana Purchase, the current city area was designated part of the 1854 Kansas Territory.The city council has nine members total, six of which represent one of six equally populated districts each.A plaque near the torii gate states that "the purpose of the sister city relationship is to promote understanding between the people of our two countries and cities".The city has abundant sunshine year-round, averaging 243 sunny days per year, and receives approximately 16.5 inches (419 mm) of annual precipitation.The defense industry is a significant part of the Colorado Springs economy, with some of the city's largest employers coming from the sector.High tech corporations with connections to the city include: Verizon Business, a telecommunications firm, had nearly 1300 employees in 2008.At one time Colorado Springs was the national headquarters for 81 different religious organizations, earning the city the tongue-in-cheek nicknames "the Evangelical Vatican" and "The Christian Mecca."The city is home to 24 national governing bodies of sport, including the United States Olympic Committee, the United States Olympic Training Center, and USA Hockey.

The city commission constitutes the governing body with powers to pass ordinances, adopt regulations, and exercise all powers conferred upon the city in the city charter.The City of Miami is governed by Mayor Francis X. Suarez and 5 city commissioners that oversee the five districts in the city.Rapid high-rise construction led to fast population growth in the city's inner neighborhoods, primarily in Downtown, Brickell and Edgewater, with these neighborhoods becoming the fastest-growing areas in the city.In October 2009, the city also approved an extensive 20-year plan for bike routes and paths around the city.Miami is also a major music recording center, with the Sony Music Latin and Universal Music Latin Entertainment headquarters in the city, along with many other smaller record labels.It is the second-largest US city (after El Paso, Texas) with a Spanish-speaking majority, and the largest city with a Cuban-American plurality.Metropolitan Miami is also a major tourism hub in the southeastern U.S. for international visitors, ranking number two in the country after New York City.As of 2010[update], 70.2% of Miami's population age five and over spoke only Spanish at home while 22.7% of the population spoke English at home.The city's frequent portrayal in music, film, and popular culture has made the city and its landmarks recognizable worldwide.Greater Downtown Miami has one of the largest concentrations of international banks in the United States, and is home to many large national and international companies.

The city is 172 miles (277 km) south of Richmond, Virginia, 278 miles (447 km) south of Washington, D.C., and 167 miles (269 km) northeast of Charlotte, North Carolina.Raleigh is known as the "City of Oaks" for its many oak trees, which line the streets in the heart of the city.No known city or town existed previously on the chosen city site.In 1997, the National Hockey League's Hartford Whalers announced their intention to move to Raleigh as the Carolina Hurricanes, becoming the city's first major league professional sports franchise.[citation needed] In 1922, WLAC signed on as the city's first radio station, but lasted only two years.The Raleigh tornado produced over $77 million in F4 damage, along with four fatalities (two in the city of Raleigh, and two in Nash County) and 154 injuries.The city's Rex Hospital opened in 1889 and included the state's first nursing school.The city's location was chosen, in part, for being within 11 mi (18 km) of Isaac Hunter's Tavern, a popular tavern frequented by the state legislators.The city covers a land area of 142.8 square miles (370 km2).Raleigh City Council consists of eight members; all seats, including the Mayor's, are open for election every two years.

Omaha has a strong mayor form of government, along with a city council elected from seven districts across the city.Omaha ranks as the 42nd-largest city in the United States, and is the core city of its 60th-largest metropolitan area.The city's Christian community has several historical churches dating from the founding of the city.The city's land has been altered considerably with substantial land grading throughout Downtown Omaha and scattered across the city.The city was founded along the Missouri River, and a crossing called Lone Tree Ferry earned the city its nickname, the "Gateway to the West".The City of Omaha Landmarks Heritage Preservation Commission is the government body that works with the mayor of Omaha and the Omaha City Council to protect historic places.By the late 1960s, the city rivaled, but never surpassed, the United States insurance centers of Hartford, Connecticut, New York City and Boston.The Omaha City Council is the legislative branch and has seven members elected from districts across the city.During Dahlman's tenure, the city switched from its original strong-mayor form of government to a city commission government.The city is also home to three of the 30 largest architecture firms in the United States, including HDR, Inc., DLR Group, Inc., and Leo A Daly.

The City Attorney, City Auditor, and City Prosecutor are also elected positions.The city is located over an oilfield with minor wells located both directly beneath the city as well as offshore.Long Beach is a full-service city that provides nearly all of its own municipal services, in contrast with a contract city.Two years previous Flint, Bixby & Co had also purchased along with Northern California associate James Irvine, three ranchos which would later become the city that bears Irvine's name.The other college-level sports team in the city is Long Beach City College.The city of Long Beach has five major Class 1 bike paths (separate off-road bike paths) within its boundaries, encompassing over 60 miles (97 km).The school also has regularly appeared in NCAA tournaments in men's baseball, men's softball, men's basketball, women's basketball, men's golf, women's tennis, men's water polo, and women's water polo.It is also the site of a major Boeing (formerly Douglas, then McDonnell Douglas) aircraft production facility, which is the city's largest non-government employer.It is the second largest city in the Los Angeles metropolitan area, the third in Southern California behind Los Angeles and San Diego.Downtown Long Beach is approximately 22 miles (35 km) south of downtown Los Angeles, though the two cities share an official border for several miles.

It is the largest city in Virginia by total area and third-largest city land area.The city of Virginia Beach is home to Virginia Beach City Public Schools, one of the largest school systems in the state (based on student enrollment).First Landing State Park and False Cape State Park are both located in coastal areas within the city's corporate limits as well.Another major park in the city is Great Neck Park, a 70 acres (28 ha) park located in the Lynnhaven District.The mayor presides over city council meetings, and serves as the ceremonial head and spokesperson of the city.Norfolk headquartered Virginia Natural Gas, a subsidiary of AGL Resources, distributes natural gas to the city from storage plants in James City County and Chesapeake.Although mostly suburban in character, it is the most populous city in Virginia and the 44th most populous city in the nation.One of the major parks is Red Wing Park, a 97 acres (39 ha) park in east-central part of the city, very close to Oceana Naval Air Station.The city's legislative body consists of an eleven-member city council.Virginia Beach is home to 210 city parks, encompassing over 4,000 acres (1,600 ha), including neighborhood parks, community parks, district parks, and other open spaces.

Other city officers include: city attorney (elected), city auditor (elected), and city clerk (appointed by city administrator).The city of Piedmont, incorporated in Oakland's central foothills after the 1906 earthquake, is a small independent city surrounded by the city of Oakland.The mayor appoints a city administrator, subject to the confirmation by the City Council, who is the city's chief administrative officer.Despite the major increases in the number and proportion of African Americans in the city, in 1966 only 16 of the city's 661 police officers were black.Catholic schools in Oakland are operated by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Oakland also include eight K–8 schools (plus one in Piedmont on the Oakland city border).It is below the 925 recommended by the city's strategic plan, and far below the approximately 1,200 recommended by an independent study commissioned by the city in the mid-1990s.An act to incorporate the city was passed on May 4, 1852, and incorporation was later approved on March 25, 1854, which officially made Oakland a city.The Oakland City Council has eight council members representing seven districts in Oakland with one member elected at-large and others from single-member districts; council members serve staggered four-year terms.In addition, the city participated in large development and urban renewal projects, concentrated especially in the downtown area, at the Port of Oakland, and at the Oakland International Airport.The city is also home to several major corporations including Kaiser Permanente, Clorox, and Dreyer's ice cream, and retailer Cost Plus World Markets.

That year, Minneapolis elected Abdi Warsame, Alondra Cano, and Blong Yang, the city's first Somali-American, Mexican-American, and Hmong-American city councilpeople, respectively.The name Minneapolis is attributed to Charles Hoag, the city's first schoolmaster, who combined mni, a Dakota Sioux word for water, and polis, the Greek word for city.In 2007 citing the city's bicycle lanes, buses and LRT, Forbes identified Minneapolis the world's fifth cleanest city.The Minneapolis City Council holds the most power and represents the city's thirteen districts called wards.The City Council passed a resolution in March 2015 making fossil fuel divestment city policy.Besides public schools, the city is home to more than 20 private schools and academies and about 20 additional charter schools.African Americans make up 18.6% of the city's population, with a large fraction hailing from Rust Belt cities such as Chicago and Gary, Indiana over the past three decades.The city and suburbs are also home to independently-owned affiliates of NBC (KARE 11), PBS (KTCA-TV/KTCI-TV 2), The CW (WUCW 23) and one independent station (KSTC-TV 45).Minneapolis is home to three opera companies: Minnesota Opera, Mill City Summer Opera and Really Spicy Opera, known for its productions of new musicals and operas.The Minneapolis Skyway System, seven miles (11 km) of enclosed pedestrian bridges called skyways, link eighty city blocks downtown.

As a whole, the council acts as the legislative body of city government, which aims to pass laws, approve the city budget, and manage efficiency in city government.A city councilor from each of the city's nine council districts is elected every two years, each serving a term of two years.In addition, the city hosts a number of galleries, experimental art-spaces, smaller museums and display spaces located throughout the city (clustered mostly in downtown, Brookside and the Pearl District).On a smaller scale, the city hosts block parties during a citywide "Block Party Day" each year, with festivals varying in size throughout city neighborhoods.A third body of the government, the city auditor, is elected independently of the city council and mayor to ensure that the auditor can act in an objective manner.In accordance with the mayor-council form of government, the Tulsa City Council and the office of the Mayor coordinate in city government operations.A mayor-council government has been in place in Tulsa since 1989 when the city converted from a city commission government deemed wasteful and less efficient. Tulsa /ˈtʌlsə/ is the second-largest city in the state of Oklahoma and 45th-most populous city in the United States.The Tulsa Metropolitan Area, or the region immediately surrounding Tulsa with strong social and economic ties to the city, occupies a large portion of the state's northeastern quadrant.The BOK Center, Tulsa's new arena, incorporates many of the city's most prominent themes, including Native American, art deco, and contemporary architectural styles.

Mansfield Timberview High School's boys basketball 2017 5A state title is the city's most recent boys basketball state title victory.The Arlington City Council is composed of the Mayor and eight City Council members.The city is served by two Interstate Highways, I-20, also known as Ronald Reagan Memorial Highway, and I-30, also named Tom Landry Memorial Highway.Bowie High School's 2005 girls basketball 5A state title is the city's most recent girls state title victory.UTA also produced Doug Russell, who won two gold medals in swimming at the Mexico City Olympics in 1968 and for whom a park on campus is named.Proposition E, backed by the mayor and city council, grants an additional year on turn limits currently at 2 years.The proposition would also allow the mayor and city council to serve three consecutive term limits.The city could boast of water, electricity, natural gas, and telephone services by 1910, along with a public school system.For many years, Arlington had the notorious distinction of being the largest city in the United States that was not served by a public transportation system.City Council extended the MAX bus service beyond the original two-year pilot timeframe through annual contracts until Dec. 31, 2017.

Several Major League baseball teams conduct spring training in the area, and most also operate minor league teams in the Class-A Florida State League.The factories in Ybor City and West Tampa made an enormous number of cigars—in the peak year of 1929, over 500,000,000 cigars were hand rolled in the city.It was during this time period in the city's history that two of the most popular tourist attractions in the area were developed – Busch Gardens and Lowry Park.Along with the city's freeways, major surface roads serve as main arteries of the city.The Tampa Smokers were the city's first minor league team, beginning play as charter members of the new Florida State League in 1919.It is on the west coast of Florida on Tampa Bay, near the Gulf of Mexico, and is the largest city in the Tampa Bay Area.The city is divided into many neighborhoods, many of which were towns and unincorporated communities annexed by the growing city.No hurricane has made landfall in the immediate Tampa Bay area since the 1921 Tampa Bay hurricane made landfall near Tarpon Springs and caused extensive damage throughout the region.Ybor City's factories rolled their first cigars in 1886, and many different cigar manufacturers moved their operations to town in ensuing years.The area has become a "de facto" headquarters of professional wrestling, with many pros living in the area.

Colleges and universities based within the city include: New Orleans Public Schools (NOPS) is the city's public school system.New Orleans' government is largely centralized in the city council and mayor's office, but it maintains earlier systems from when various sections of the city managed their affairs separately.In January 2007, several thousand New Orleans residents marched to City Hall for a rally demanding police and city leaders tackle the crime problem.The 1809 migration brought 2,731 whites, 3,102 free people of color (of mixed-race European and African descent), and 3,226 slaves of primarily African descent, doubling the city's population.Large numbers of rural ex-slaves and some free people of color from the city volunteered for the first regiments of Black troops in the War.New Orleans' economy had always been based more on trade and financial services than on manufacturing, but the city's relatively small manufacturing sector also shrank after World War II.Pierre Le Blond de Tour and Adrien de Pauger, for example, planned many early fortifications, along with the street plan for the city of New Orleans.As the middle class and wealthier members of both races left the center city, its population's income level dropped, and it became proportionately more African American.The city's music was later also significantly influenced by Acadiana, home of Cajun and Zydeco music, and by Delta blues.The city anchors the larger New Orleans metropolitan area, which had an estimated population of 1,275,762 in 2017.

In the late 1990s and 2000s, the city government and local organizations began collaborating to re-develop downtown Wichita and older neighborhoods in the city.In terms of population, Wichita is the largest city in Kansas and the 48th largest city in the United States.K-15, a north-south route, enters the city from the south and joins I-135 and U.S. 81 in south-central Wichita, running concurrently with them through the rest of the city.The city's Old Cowtown Museum maintains historical artifacts and exhibits on the city's early history.By 1890, Wichita had become the third-largest city in the state after Kansas City and Topeka with a population of nearly 24,000.The council sets policy for the city, enacts laws and ordinances, levies taxes, approves the city budget, and appoints members to citizen commission and advisory boards.It operates more than 90 schools in the city including 10 high schools, 16 middle schools, 61 elementary schools, and more than a dozen special schools and programs.The largest is the Little Arkansas River, which enters the city from the north and joins the Arkansas immediately west of downtown.The Roman Catholic Diocese of Wichita oversees 16 Catholic schools in the city including 14 elementary schools and two high schools, Bishop Carroll Catholic High School and Kapaun Mt.The Chisholm's own tributaries drain much of the city's eastern half; these include the creek's West, Middle, and East Forks as well as, further south, Gypsum Creek.

The city proper has a population of 385,525, making it the 51st-largest city in the United States, and the second-largest city in Ohio.The city's population reached its peak of 914,808, and in 1949 Cleveland was named an All-America City for the first time.In 1836, the city, then only on the eastern banks of the Cuyahoga River, nearly erupted into open warfare with neighboring Ohio City over a bridge connecting the two.By 1920, due in large part to the city's economic prosperity, Cleveland became the nation's fifth-largest city.The city has many nicknames, the oldest of which in contemporary use being "The Forest City".The Terminal Tower, dedicated in 1930, was the tallest building in North America outside New York City until 1964 and the tallest in the city until 1991.Cleveland is home to Playhouse Square Center, the second largest performing arts center in the United States behind New York City's Lincoln Center.Cleveland also hosts an annual holiday display lighting and celebration, dubbed Winterfest, which is held downtown at the city's historic hub, Public Square.These neighborhoods are on both the west side (Ohio City, Tremont, Detroit-Shoreway, and Edgewater) and the east side (Collinwood, Hough, Fairfax, and Little Italy).Cleveland's most walkable and transient areas can be found in the Downtown, Ohio City, Detroit-Shoreway, University Circle, and Buckeye-Shaker Square neighborhoods.

The City Manager, in turn, appoints (does not require confirmation from the City Council) the Finance Director, City Clerk, and Deputy City Clerk.The department protects the city, split between two areas: West area and East area, with police headquarters in the east and the west substation serving west Bakersfield.The City Council appoints and confirms (which the mayor does cast a vote ) both the City Attorney and the City Manager.Bakersfield's population is around 380,000, making it the 9th-most populous city in California and the 52nd-most populous city in the nation.The city of Shafter, a small farming town north of Bakersfield, previously filed a suit to attempt to limit the northern expansion of Bakersfield's city limits.North of the city, each railroad uses its own rail lines; south of the city, they share a line owned by Union Pacific.ECC is a joint dispatch center for the Kern County, Bakersfield City and California City Fire Departments.Little information is known about the City Charter adopted in 1873, or in 1898, when the city was incorporated.The more built-up urban area that includes Bakersfield and areas immediately around the city, such as East Bakersfield, Oildale, and Rosedale, has a population of over 520,000.Due to a vast number of county islands and jagged city limit lines in the south part of Bakersfield, the closest fire station is dispatched to incidents.

The city of Aurora operates under a council-manager form of government, where the city manager runs the city's day-to-day operations with general guidance from the city council.A consolidated city and county of Aurora would likely include areas not within the current city limits, but the new city-county boundaries would be set, restricting future expansion.A consolidated city and county government was considered in the mid-1990s but failed to win approval by city voters.The city's official elevation, posted on signs at the city limits, is 5,471 feet (1,668 m).Colorado voters created the City and County of Denver in 1902 and the City and County of Broomfield in 2001.In 1965, mayor Norma O. Walker became the first woman to head a U.S. city with a population over 60,000.Aurora's mayor role is largely ceremonial, but the mayor does have direct impact on policy issues as the head of city council.The city attracts more than 30 regional and national sports tournaments annually to Aurora's fields, which include the 220-acre (0.89 km2) Aurora Sports Park opened in 2003.The Aurora City Council is composed of a mayor and ten council members.The median income for a household in the city was $46,507, and the median income for a family was $52,551.

Under the city's term limits, an individual may serve a maximum of two terms as a city council member and two terms as the mayor.Anaheim Hills is a master-planned[peacock term] community located in the city's eastern stretches that is home to many of the city's affluent.Legislative authority is vested in a city council of seven nonpartisan members, who hire a professional city manager to oversee day-to-day operations.Downtown is the administrative heart of the city where City Hall, Anaheim West Tower, Anaheim Police Headquarters, the Anaheim Chamber of Commerce and the Main Library are located.Voters elected the mayor and four other members of the city council to serve four-year staggered terms.A Public Utilities Board, made up of Anaheim residents, advises the City Council on major utility issues.They argued that a name change was a major bargaining chip in negotiations between the city and Disney Baseball Enterprises, Inc., then the ownership group for the Angels.The mayor serves as the presiding officer of the city council in a first among equals role.Reported rapes the city are relatively uncommon as well, but have been increasing, along with the national average.Many hotels, especially in the city's Resort district, serve theme park tourists and conventiongoers.

Samoan Americans made up 1.5% of the population, Marshallese people make up 0.5% of the city's population, and Tongan people comprise 0.3% of its population.It is also the most populated Oceanian city outside Australasia and ranks second to Auckland as the most-populous city in Polynesia.Honolulu is the most remote city of its size in the world and is the westernmost and southernmost major U.S. city.As of 2015[update], Honolulu was ranked high on world livability rankings, and was also ranked as the 2nd safest city in the U.S.The Capitol District is within the Honolulu census county division (CCD), the urban area commonly regarded as the "City" of Honolulu.It is an unincorporated part of and the county seat of the City and County of Honolulu along the southeast coast of the island of Oʻahu.It is endowed with the state's largest collection of natural history specimens and the world's largest collection of Hawaiiana and Pacific culture artifacts.The Hawaiʻi State Art Museum (also downtown) boasts pieces by local artists as well as traditional Hawaiian art.Temperatures vary little throughout the months, with average high temperatures of 80–90 °F (27–32 °C) and average lows of 65–75 °F (18–24 °C) throughout the year.The team went undefeated en route to the United States championship game, where it bested Georgia's Peachtree City American Little League team 3-0.

Founded in 1869, the city is part of the Greater Los Angeles Area, the second largest metropolitan area in the United States, with almost 18 million residents in 2010.The southeast end of the city is part of the South Coast Metro area, which is shared with the city of Costa Mesa.Despite the city's high percentage of Democrats, however, the city tends to vote conservatively on social issues, much like the rest of northern Orange County.Santa Ana is a very densely populated city, ranking fourth nationally in that regard among cities of over 300,000 residents (trailing only New York City, San Francisco, and Boston).Mayor Miguel Pulido is currently under investigation by the city attorney for a property swap involving a city contractor, in which the mayor ended up profiting $200,000.Santa Ana Unified School District includes 37 K–5 elementary schools, nine 6–8 intermediate schools, eight 9–12 high schools, five special schools, and one charter school.
